question: In aged mice, does exogenous fibronectin (FN) administration impair skeletal muscle regeneration and decrease muscle stem cell numbers? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Reconstitution of FN levels in the aged niche remobilizes stem cells and restores youth-like muscle regeneration.
content.source_2: Systemic administration of fibronectin (FN) to old mice attenuated MuSC activation and impaired myofiber repair relative to saline, indicating that FN treatment compromises regenerative potential in aged muscle.
content.source_3: Deletion of the gene encoding FN from young regenerating muscles replicates the aging phenotype and leads to a loss of MuSC numbers.
content.source_4: In a blinded, randomized design, localized deposition of FN into aged muscle wounds led to a dose-dependent decline in satellite cell numbers and slower functional recovery versus untreated controls.
